Wesley, I wanted to second Jason's suggestion that you try it outside coe=
volution first.  Coevolution can sometimes hide underlying bugs or issues t=
hat are therefore difficult to rule out.  If you try an exhaustive approach=
 like Jason's, you can at least know that the system is otherwise functioni=
ng properly.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "jgmath2000" <jgmath2000@..=
.> wrote:
>
> You might want to try to evolve a player without coevolution =
first  to make sure that everything else is working.  In my HyperNEAT libra=
ry, I have a tic tac toe experiment where the evaluation plays against an "=
everything" player.  Basically, whenever it is the everything player's turn=
, that player creates a new game for every possible action.  In other words=
, if the everything player moves first, he creates nine copies of the game =
state, one for each first move, and the hyperneat player plays all nine of =
these games (which then expand into more games, etc.)  This is tractable be=
cause tic tac toe is such a small search space.  I like this approach becau=
se it is easy to know when you have achieved a perfect player, since every =
possible game state that could be reached given the individual's current po=
licy is presented.
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Wesley Tansey <tans=
ey@> wrote:

er is X, similar to the host-parasite setup I

t 2, but no luck so far. The only other ideas I 
> > have left are to drast=
ically increase the population size or to add in 
> > an optimal opponent w=
ith random noise like Fogel did originally. I 
> > hesitate to do the latte=
r though, as coevolution is generally a more 
> > elegant solution.
